channel.title: Image & Applet
channel.description: ive looked all over the place and cant find a way of getting a Image of the applet

item.title: Image & Applet
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

theres two way i can think of around this

one way is to make your own class java.awt.Canvas thats the same as the real one, and override getGraphics(), then use the non-standard option “-Xbootclasspath/p” to add your class before the real java library classes

or you could do some client-editing, there is a class in the runescape client which is a subclass of java.awt.Canvas, find it and use a bytecode library to change its superclass to one of your classes which extends java.awt.Canvas, then override getGraphics() as above

once you have getGraphics(), you can “return image.createGraphics();” instead of the real ones, or you can mess about it a bit so it paints on both, or some other way, experiment!

Read full topic

item.title: Image & Applet
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

BAsh(CntLgn):

It doesn’t work because they paint their stuff directly on a canvas object. They call getGraphics() and use that. They don’t touch the passed parameter.

Moparisthebest.com > Programming > Java programming

Read full topic

item.title: Image & Applet
item.dc:creator: @Interdit Interdit
item.description:
@Interdit wrote:

Try paint’ing the applet onto your own Image. Or repaint(). Whatever.

This is merely one possibility, it depends how the application is designed. [br][br][size=1]Posted on: February 09, 2008, 08:33:02 PM[/size][hr]For example:

[code]Applet existingApplet;

BufferedImage img = new BufferedImage(WIDTH, HEIGHT, BufferedImage.TYPE_INT_RGB);
Graphics g = img.createGraphics();
existingApplet.paint(g);[/code]

Read full topic
